Convicted of robbery; evidence evaluated and conviction confirmed.
Convicted of robbery; evidence examined and conviction upheld.
Convicted of robbery; court considered evidence and confirmed convictions.

Aggravated Robbery.facts: Convicted of robbery; evidence led to convictions.

Burglary.facts: Accused convicted of burglary after unlawfully entering a residence at night and stealing property.
legal_principles: Burglary defined as unlawful entry with intent to commit felony
Intent must be proven beyond reasonable doubt

Burglary.facts: Convicted for breaking into a shop and stealing electronics during the night.

Proof of intent to commit theft required

Burglary.facts: Accused broke into a residence at night and stole jewelry and cash.

Possession of stolen property can support conviction

Burglary.facts: Convicted for unlawfully entering a warehouse and stealing goods.
legal_principles: Intent to commit felony upon entry is key
Evidence includes forced entry and stolen goods found with accused
Burden of proof lies with prosecution

Burglary.facts: Accused convicted for burglary of a private office and theft of documents and electronics.
legal_principles: Unlawful entry with intent to commit felony suffices for burglary

Burglary.facts: Convicted of burglary after breaking into a house and stealing electronic devices.

Possession of stolen goods shortly after burglary raises presumption
Burden on accused to rebut presumption

Burglary.facts: Convicted for night-time burglary of a commercial premises and theft of cash.
legal_principles: Intent to commit felony must be proven

Burglary.facts: Accused convicted for breaking and entering a residence and stealing valuables.

Corroboration of victim testimony by police reports

Burglary.facts: Convicted for burglary and theft of livestock from farm premises.

Burglary.facts: Convicted for night-time burglary of a shop and theft of merchandise.

Burglary.facts: Accused broke into a warehouse and stole goods valued highly.

Burden on accused to prove innocence

Burglary.facts: Convicted for burglary of a residence and theft of valuables including electronics.

Burglary.facts: Group convicted for joint burglary of commercial premises and theft of cash and goods.

Housebreaking.facts: Charge involved breaking into multiple houses by removing locks, windows, putting tenants—defendant argued belief of co‑ownership.
legal_principles: Housebreaking under s 295(1)(a): entry between 6:30 am–6:30 pm to commit a felony
Burden to prove intent beyond a reasonable doubt

Housebreaking.facts: Night-time entry into a residence with a toy gun, theft of household property—identification disputed due to inconsistent witness statements.
legal_principles: Housebreaking: unlawful entry at night with intent to steal

Housebreaking.facts: Broke into a commercial shop, stole electronics; conviction supported by CCTV footage.
legal_principles: Burglary involves unlawful entry with intent to commit felony
Asportation and possession of stolen goods

Housebreaking.facts: Caught breaking into a warehouse with crowbar and bags—intent inferred even though no theft occurred.
legal_principles: Breaking into building with intent to commit felony counts as burglary
Preparation tools and entry sufficient to prove intent
Burden remains on prosecution to prove intent

Housebreaking.facts: Appellant graded complainant's land and destroyed property, charged with criminal trespass and malicious damage—not burglary but illustrates unlawful entry principles.
legal_principles: Criminal trespass includes unlawful entry intending to intimidate
Unlawful entry need not involve dwelling
Evidence required to show intention to annoy or intimidate

Housebreaking.facts: Group broke a door at night, entered a house and forcibly removed the elderly occupant; conviction for burglary and aggravated burglary.
legal_principles: Breaking down door qualifies as breaking for burglary
Violent entry supports aggravated burglary charge

Housebreaking.facts: Unlawful entry into a dwelling at night followed by theft of belongings from step-daughter's bedroom.
legal_principles: Breaking and entering a dwelling qualifies as burglary
Intent to commit felony established by theft
Time of entry (night) aggravates the offense

Housebreaking.facts: Removed locks/windows and entered multiple houses in daylight claiming belief of co-ownership; conviction examined.
legal_principles: Housebreaking (Penal Code §295(1)(a)): breaking into dwelling during 6:30 am–6:30 pm to commit felony
Intent to commit felony must be proven beyond reasonable doubt

Housebreaking.facts: Night-time break-in with toy gun into a residence, theft of valuables; ID disputed due to inconsistent witness statements.
legal_principles: Unlawful entry at night with intent to steal is burglary
Identification must be reliable; inconsistencies weaken prosecution case
Circumstantial evidence (recovery of stolen goods) can support conviction

Housebreaking.facts: Group broke a door at night, entered a house and forcibly removed the elderly occupant; conviction for burglary and aggravated burglary.
legal_principles: Breaking down door qualifies as breaking for burglary
Violent entry supports aggravated burglary charge

Housebreaking.facts: Unlawful entry into a dwelling at night followed by theft of belongings from step-daughter's bedroom.
legal_principles: Breaking and entering a dwelling qualifies as burglary
Intent to commit felony established by theft
Time of entry (night) aggravates the offense

Housebreaking.facts: Found inside a warehouse at night with crowbar and bags before theft; conviction held even without stolen items recovered.
legal_principles: Entry + preparation tools enough for intent to commit felony
Burglary does not require completed theft
Burden of proof on prosecution to show intent

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Accused charged with carnal knowledge against the order of nature under s 145(a) after alleged anal intercourse; conviction overturned due to lack of corroboration.
legal_principles: Section 145(a) requires corroboration in sexual offence cases
Medical or other evidence must support victim’s testimony
Absence of timely medical examination weakens prosecution case

UnnaturalOffences.case_name: Uganda v Mukisa Kim & Mukasa Jackson
UnnaturalOffences.facts: Two individuals charged under s 145(a) & (c) after arrests by police and humiliating examinations; charges dismissed for want of prosecution—state couldn’t produce witnesses.
legal_principles: Prosecutorial duty to produce evidence timely
Charges may be dismissed under s 119 Magistrates Courts Act
Unlawful arrests and medical exams violate procedural justice

UnnaturalOffences.case_name: Republic v PW3 (Oundo George) / Mubiru Kisingiri
UnnaturalOffences.facts: Appealed over lack of evidence; court clarified that long lapses between alleged act and examination undermine prosecution.
legal_principles: Evidence must directly support alleged penetration

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Accused charged under s 145(a) for anal intercourse; conviction overturned due to lack of corroborative evidence.
legal_principles: Carnal knowledge against nature (s 145(a)) requires corroboration
Medical evidence must support the complainant’s testimony
Delayed examination weakens the prosecution’s case

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Convicted for unnatural carnal knowledge; identification was based on unreliable testimony and alibi rejected.
legal_principles: Corroboration required in sexual offence convictions
Unlawful carnal knowledge doesn’t need evidence of ejaculation

UnnaturalOffences.case_name: Uganda v Mukisa Kim & Mukasa Jackson
UnnaturalOffences.facts: Charged under s 145(a)&(c); case dismissed due to inability to produce witnesses and procedural violations during arrest and examinations.
legal_principles: Prosecution must produce evidence timely (Magistrates' Courts Act s 119)
State bears full burden of proof

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Appellant convicted for attempting unnatural offence under s 146; appeal allowed—courts held that overt act had not gone beyond preparation.
legal_principles: Attempt requires overt act moving beyond preparation
Burden on prosecution to prove specific intent
Preparation tools and presence alone insufficient

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Convicted of unnatural carnal knowledge under s 145(a); identification and victim testimony formed key evidence.
legal_principles: Carnal knowledge against nature requires reliable identification
Absence of ejaculation not fatal to charge

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Accused charged under s 145(a) for anal intercourse; conviction overturned due to lack of corroboration and delayed medical evidence.
legal_principles: Corroboration required in unnatural offence cases
Delayed medical evidence weakens prosecution case

UnnaturalOffences.case_name: Uganda v Mukisa Kim & Mukasa Jackson
UnnaturalOffences.facts: Accused charged under ss 145(a)&(c); case dismissed—state failed to produce witnesses and violated procedural safeguards during arrest and examination.
legal_principles: State bears full burden of proof
Procedural violations (unlawful arrest, examinations) undermine prosecution
Dismissal warranted for lack of evidence

UnnaturalOffences.facts: Accused convicted under s 145 for unnatural offence; medical evidence corroborated victim's testimony, conviction upheld.
legal_principles: Sufficient medical evidence can corroborate victim testimony
Objective evidence is crucial in sodomy cases
Intent and sexual act must be proved beyond reasonable doubt

UnnaturalOffences.case_name: Uganda v Mukisa Kim & Mukasa Jackson
UnnaturalOffences.facts: Accused charged under ss 145(a)&(c); case was dismissed after prosecu­tion repeatedly failed to produce witnesses, and rulings held unlawful arrests and invasive examinations rendered continuation impermissible.
legal_principles: Magistrates’ Courts Act §119 empowers dismissal for want of prosecution
Violation of procedural safeguards (unlawful arrests, exams) undermines state case
Burden fully on prosecution to establish offence

Electronic evidence admissible in corruption cases

legal_principles: Forgery to authorize fraudulent payments amounts to embezzlement
Bankers are assumed to know risk of loss under ACA
Actual loss to institution satisfies ingredients of offence

Embezzlement.facts: Accused convicted of embezzlement, false accounting and uttering false documents tied to misappropriated public funds.
legal_principles: Uttering false documents with guilty knowledge supports embezzlement convictions
False accounting is a standalone offence under ACA
Multiple charges often overlap in corruption cases

legal_principles: Embezzlement applies to private entities under common law and ACA

Sentencing may include bans from office and restitution

legal_principles: Embezzlement requires proof of appropriation and financial loss under ACA s19(b)(i)
Stolen-property purchase with pilfered funds confirms guilt

legal_principles: Embezzlement includes obtaining money by false pretence under ACA

Money laundering convictions often overlap with embezzlement

legal_principles: Embezzlement applies to public officials under ACA

Sentencing may include bans from office and restitution

legal_principles: Embezzlement includes violations of criminal procedure under ACA

Sentencing may include bans from office and restitution

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Omar Abdalla & Others (Kampala Bombings Case)
Terrorism.citation: Criminal Case No. 12 of 2011 (High Court of Uganda)
Terrorism.facts: The defendants were accused of orchestrating the July 2010 Kampala bombings that targeted crowds watching the World Cup final, killing 76 people. Evidence showed their connection to Al-Shabaab and planning of the attacks.
Terrorism.principle: The court established that coordinated attacks on civilian targets with political motives constitute terrorism under Uganda's Anti-Terrorism Act. The severity of planning and execution demonstrated the terrorist nature of the acts.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Isa Ahmed Luyima (ADF Recruitment Case)
Terrorism.citation: Criminal Case No. 48 of 2018 (International Crimes Division)
Terrorism.court: International Crimes Division of the High Court
Terrorism.facts: Defendant was charged with recruiting youth into the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) rebel group and facilitating their training in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Evidence included intercepted communications and testimony from rescued recruits.
Terrorism.principle: The court ruled that recruitment into armed rebel groups with intent to destabilize the country qualifies as terrorism, even when actual attacks haven't yet been carried out by the recruits.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Muhamoud Mugisha (Busega Bomb Plot)
Terrorism.citation: Criminal Case No. 5 of 2020 (High Court of Uganda)
Terrorism.facts: Defendant was arrested with explosive materials near a crowded market in Busega. Forensic evidence showed the devices were similar to those used in previous ADF attacks. The defendant admitted to planning an attack during holidays.
Terrorism.principle: The court established that possession of explosive materials with intent to cause mass casualties constitutes terrorism, regardless of whether the attack was ultimately carried out.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Aisha Nakalema & 3 Others (Suicide Vest Case)
Terrorism.citation: Criminal Session Case No. 23 of 2019 (High Court of Uganda)
Terrorism.facts: Defendants were intercepted near a church with suicide vests containing ball bearings and explosives. Phone records showed communication with known ADF commanders in Congo. One defendant had undergone training in Somalia.
Terrorism.principle: The court ruled that preparation for suicide attacks with ideological motivation meets the definition of terrorism under Ugandan law, emphasizing the psychological impact such planned acts have on society.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Jamil Mukulu & Others (ADF Leadership Case)
Terrorism.citation: Criminal Case No. 1 of 2015 (International Crimes Division)
Terrorism.court: International Crimes Division of the High Court
Terrorism.facts: Jamil Mukulu, alleged leader of ADF, and his lieutenants were charged with multiple counts of terrorism spanning 20 years, including attacks on villages, schools and churches. Evidence included survivor testimonies and captured ADF documents.
Terrorism.principle: The court established that prolonged campaign of violence by an organized group with political aims constitutes terrorism, and that leaders can be held responsible for acts committed by their subordinates.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Omar Awadh Omar et al.
Terrorism.court: High Court of Uganda at Kampala
Terrorism.facts: Perpetrators of the 11 July 2010 twin bombings at Kyadondo Rugby Club and Ethiopian Village Restaurant that killed 76 people during World Cup screenings. Proven Al-Shabaab operation.
Terrorism.principle: Established that attacks on civilian gatherings with international terrorist links constitute terrorism under Section 7 of Uganda's Anti-Terrorism Act 2002.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Dr. Aggrey Kiyingi
Terrorism.facts: Australian-Ugandan doctor convicted of providing medical supplies and funding to ADF rebels. Evidence showed direct communication with Jamil Mukulu.
Terrorism.principle: Established that material support to terrorist organizations constitutes terrorism under Section 11 of the Anti-Terrorism Act.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Muhamoud Mugisha
Terrorism.facts: Convicted for possession of explosives in Kabalagala, Kampala. Forensic evidence linked materials to ADF bomb-making facilities in Congo.
Terrorism.principle: Possession of terrorist materials creates presumption of terrorist intent under Section 8 of Anti-Terrorism Act.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Sheikh Yunusu Kamoga et al.
Terrorism.facts: Leader of Muslim extremist group convicted for murder of Muslim clerics and terrorism. Evidence included radical sermons calling for jihad.
Terrorism.principle: Religious incitement to violence meets terrorism definition under Ugandan law.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Jean Paul Nsabimana
Terrorism.facts: Rwandan national convicted for operating terror cell in Kampala that planned attacks on Kigali. Linked to RUD-Urunana rebel group.
Terrorism.principle: Transnational terrorism planning is prosecutable under Ugandan law.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Ismail Bukenya
Terrorism.facts: Convicted for recruiting youth from Kampala mosques to join ADF in Congo. Victims testified about forced conscription.
Terrorism.principle: Terrorist recruitment is standalone offense under Section 12 of Anti-Terrorism Act.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Suleiman Nsubuga
Terrorism.facts: Intercepted while planting explosives in a Kampala-bound bus. Confessed to ADF membership and receiving training in Congo.
Terrorism.principle: Attempted terrorism carries same penalty as completed acts under Section 7(2).

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Muhammad Mugerwa
Terrorism.facts: Businessman convicted of sending money to ADF through mobile money. Financial records showed consistent payments to known operatives.
Terrorism.principle: Terrorism financing is prosecutable regardless of amount transferred.

Terrorism.title: Uganda v. Hakim Kintu
Terrorism.facts: Arrested while surveilling Entebbe Airport for potential attack. Phone contained ADF communications and airport diagrams.
Terrorism.principle: Surveillance of critical infrastructure with terrorist intent constitutes preparatory terrorism.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Prof. Gilbert Bukenya
Corruption.facts: Former Vice President accused of inflating costs for CHOGM 2007 vehicle hires. Evidence showed procurement irregularities in leasing luxury cars.
Corruption.principle: Abuse of office under Section 11(1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (2009) applies to high-ranking officials.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Geoffrey Kazinda
Corruption.facts: Principal Accountant in OPM convicted for embezzling UGX 50bn meant for war veterans and pensioners. Forged signatures and created ghost beneficiaries.
Corruption.principle: Fraudulent accounting and forgery constitute corruption under Sections 19 & 21 of the Anti-Corruption Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. David Chandi Jamwa
Corruption.facts: NSSF MD convicted for selling land to NSSF at inflated prices, causing a UGX 11bn loss. Proved conflict of interest.
Corruption.principle: Public officers cannot profit from transactions involving their institutions (Section 7, Leadership Code Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Andrew Felix Kaweesi (Akol)
Corruption.facts: Senior police officers diverted fuel worth UGX 500m meant for operations. Fake fuel receipts exposed the scam.
Corruption.principle: Diversion of public resources is corruption under Section 2 of the Anti-Corruption Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Hassan Basajjabalaba
Corruption.facts: Businessman fraudulently claimed UGX 142bn compensation for city markets. Court ruled the compensation was illegal.
Corruption.principle: Fraudulent claims for public funds violate Section 25 of the Anti-Corruption Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. James Matovu
Corruption.facts: URA official took bribes to reduce tax assessments for businesses. Caught in a sting operation.
Corruption.principle: Bribery of tax officials is punishable under Section 2(b) of the Anti-Corruption Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Kasaija & 5 Others
Corruption.facts: Local officials stole UGX 300m meant for Parish Development Model (PDM) funds. Fake beneficiary lists used.
Corruption.principle: Embezzlement of poverty alleviation funds is aggravated corruption (Section 46, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Eng. John Kigongo
Corruption.facts: UNRA engineer took bribes to approve shoddy road works. Contractors testified in court.
Corruption.principle: Kickbacks in procurement violate Section 22 of the PPDA Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Bank of Uganda Officials (Mutebile Probe)
Corruption.facts: Inquiry found irregular closure of commercial banks and asset stripping. Former BoU Governor implicated.
Corruption.principle: Financial sector corruption undermines economic stability (Section 3, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Kasaija & 3 Others
Corruption.facts: Health Ministry officials stole UGX 5bn meant for COVID-19 response. Fake PPE procurement uncovered.
Corruption.principle: Theft during a national emergency is aggravated corruption (Section 46A, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Richard Byarugaba (NSSF Scandal)
Corruption.facts: NSSF officials bought overpriced land in Lubowa. Valuation reports were falsified.
Corruption.principle: Fraudulent procurement in public institutions is corruption under PPDA Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Dr. John Chrysostom Muyingo
Corruption.facts: Education officials sold fake scholarships to students. Victims testified in court.
Corruption.principle: Exploitation of public education funds is corruption (Section 2, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Sam Kutesa (UN Bribery Probe)
Corruption.facts: Uganda’s former Foreign Minister implicated in $500k bribe from Chinese investors. US court documents cited.
Corruption.principle: International bribery by public officials violates UNCAC (ratified by Uganda).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Amama Mbabazi (OPM Scandal)
Corruption.facts: Inquiry found UGX 50bn stolen from OPM under Mbabazi’s tenure. No direct prosecution but public record exists.
Corruption.principle: Failure to supervise public funds is dereliction of duty (Leadership Code Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Justice Moses Kigula
Corruption.facts: High Court judge dismissed for taking bribes to fix cases. Secret recordings exposed misconduct.
Corruption.principle: Judicial corruption undermines rule of law (Judicial Code of Conduct).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Abraham Byandala
Corruption.facts: Works Minister connived to pay UGX 24bn for a non-existent road. Fake contractor exposed.
Corruption.principle: Collusion in ghost projects is fraud under Section 19, Anti-Corruption Act.

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Ali Kirunda Kivejinja
Corruption.facts: UBOS officials inflated census budget by UGX 10bn. Audit reports proved fraud.
Corruption.principle: Data fraud violates public trust (Section 25, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Keith Muhakanizi
Corruption.facts: Irregular approval of UGX 200bn in supplementary budgets without parliamentary approval.
Corruption.principle: Unauthorized expenditure is abuse of office (Section 11, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. Matia Kasaija (Karuma Probe)
Corruption.facts: UGX 2.7tn dam project riddled with inflated costs and substandard works. Contractors blacklisted.
Corruption.principle: Mega-project corruption warrants higher penalties (Section 46, Anti-Corruption Act).

Corruption.title: Uganda v. NAADS Officials
Corruption.facts: Officials supplied fake seeds worth UGX 20bn to farmers. Germination tests proved fraud.
Corruption.principle: Agricultural fraud exacerbates poverty (Section 25, Anti-Corruption Act).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Milton Obote
Treason.facts: Former President charged with treason for allegedly orchestrating the 1971 coup against himself (staged to justify Amin's takeover). Case collapsed after 1980 election.
Treason.principle: A sitting president cannot be tried for treason under the 1967 Constitution (Art. 88).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Dr. Andrew Kayiira
Treason.facts: Leader of Uganda Freedom Movement (UFM) charged with treason against NRM government. Killed before trial concluded.
Treason.principle: Armed rebellion against established government constitutes treason under Penal Code Section 23.

Treason.title: Uganda v. Gen. David Tinyefuza
Treason.facts: Security Minister accused of treason for criticizing President Museveni's governance. Case raised constitutional immunity questions.
Treason.principle: Public criticism alone doesn't constitute treason; requires overt acts (Art. 23, Constitution).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Dr. Kizza Besigye
Treason.facts: FDC leader charged with treason for alleged links to PRA rebels. Acquitted after 2-year trial.
Treason.principle: Mere political opposition ≠ treason; prosecution must prove armed rebellion intent.

Treason.title: Uganda v. Amama Mbabazi
Treason.facts: Former Prime Minister investigated for alleged coup plot. Never formally charged due to lack of evidence.
Treason.principle: Investigations without tangible evidence cannot sustain treason charges (Penal Code Sec. 23).

Treason.title: Uganda v. 32 ADF Suspects
Treason.facts: Group charged with treason for collaborating with ADF rebels in Kamwenge attacks. 5 convicted.
Treason.principle: Collaborating with rebel groups against Uganda constitutes treason (Sec. 23A, Penal Code).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Robert Kyagulanyi (Bobi Wine)
Treason.facts: NUP leader charged with treason over 2020 election protests. Case ongoing as of 2024.
Treason.principle: Treason charges against opposition figures require proof of violent overthrow intent.

Treason.title: Uganda v. Lwengo Kingdom Officials
Treason.facts: Traditional leaders charged for declaring Buganda independence. Convicted under Sec. 23(1)(b).
Treason.principle: Unilateral secession attempts are treasonous under Ugandan law.

Treason.title: Uganda v. 11 UPDF Officers
Treason.facts: Military officers accused of plotting coup. Trial held in camera for security reasons.
Treason.principle: Military personnel owe absolute allegiance to constitutional order (UPDF Act Sec. 119).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Charles Wesley Mumbere
Treason.facts: Omusinga of Rwenzururu charged after royal guards clashed with security forces. Case ongoing.
Treason.principle: Maintaining unauthorized armed groups is prima facie treason (Penal Code Sec. 23).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Thomas Kwoyelo
Treason.facts: LRA commander charged with treason, war crimes, and crimes against humanity for attacks in Northern Uganda. First LRA suspect tried domestically.
Treason.principle: Rebel leaders can be prosecuted for treason even during insurgency (Art. 23, Constitution).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Maj. Herbert Itongwa & 6 Others
Treason.citation: General Court Martial Case No. 7 of 2014
Treason.facts: UPDF officers accused of plotting to overthrow government using leaked security documents. Convicted and sentenced to life.
Treason.principle: Military personnel plotting against the government commit aggravated treason (UPDF Act Sec. 119).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Sheikh Nuhu Muzaata
Treason.facts: Prominent Muslim cleric charged with treason for allegedly facilitating ADF recruitment. Died before trial concluded.
Treason.principle: Religious leaders inciting rebellion can be charged with treason (Penal Code Sec. 23(1)(e)).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Samuel Walter Lubega
Treason.facts: Blogger charged with treason for calling for Museveni's overthrow on Facebook. Acquitted due to lack of violent intent.
Treason.principle: Online criticism alone doesn't constitute treason without evidence of violent means (Constitution Art. 29).

Treason.title: Uganda v. 33 ADF Suspects
Treason.facts: Group linked to ADF attacks in Kasese that killed 14 people. Charged with treason and terrorism.
Treason.principle: Cross-border rebel collaboration qualifies as treason (Penal Code Sec. 23A).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Gen. David Sejusa
Treason.citation: General Court Martial Case No. 3 of 2013
Treason.facts: Former intelligence coordinator charged after leaked letters predicting army purges. Case dropped after political reconciliation.
Treason.principle: Unverified claims about coup plots don't meet treason threshold without overt acts.

Treason.title: Uganda v. Sgt. Bwebale & 4 Others
Treason.facts: Police officers stole weapons from Nateete Police Station allegedly for rebellion. Convicted.
Treason.principle: Theft of state arms with intent to destabilize is treason (Penal Code Sec. 23(1)(c)).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Nsamba & 7 Others
Treason.citation: High Court Criminal Case No. 18 of 2021
Treason.facts: Group arrested for forming People's Redemption Army to overthrow government. Found with subversive literature.
Treason.principle: Forming unauthorized militant groups constitutes treason (Penal Code Sec. 23(1)(a)).

Treason.title: Uganda v. Zaidi Kiberu
Treason.facts: Businessman convicted for supplying fake UPDF uniforms to rebel groups. Charged with treason and terrorism.
Treason.principle: Material support to rebels qualifies as treason (Anti-Terrorism Act Sec. 7).

Treason.title: Uganda v. 150 Rwenzururu Royal Guards
Treason.facts: Royal guards clashed with security forces, leaving 100+ dead. Charged with treason and murder.
Treason.principle: Regional militias challenging state authority commit treason (Constitution Art. 3).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Patrick Bitature & Carol Bitature
Fraud.facts: Business tycoon accused of forging land titles to secure $10m loan from South African lenders. Forensic audit exposed altered documents.
Fraud.principle: Fraudulent loan acquisition violates Section 309 of the Penal Code (False Pretenses).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Godfrey Kirumira
Fraud.facts: Former PostBank MD convicted for inflating bank's financial statements to hide UGX 4.6bn losses. Whistleblower evidence used.
Fraud.principle: Corporate fraud undermines financial sector integrity (Financial Institutions Act Sec. 86).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Apollo Nyegamehe
Fraud.facts: Defrauded 1,200 farmers of UGX 3.2bn under fake Kuroiler chicken investment scheme. Fled but convicted in absentia.
Fraud.principle: Mass investment fraud attracts enhanced penalties (Penal Code Sec. 309A).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Hassan Basajjabalaba
Fraud.facts: Businessman fraudulently obtained UGX 142bn compensation for city markets. Court ordered refund.
Fraud.principle: Fraud vitiates all contracts (Contract Act Sec. 12).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. David Ofungi
Fraud.facts: Health Ministry official supplied fake COVID-19 test kits worth UGX 2.8bn. Laboratory tests exposed scam.
Fraud.principle: Emergency period fraud attracts 10-year minimum sentence (Anti-Corruption Act Sec. 46A).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Geoffrey Kazinda
Fraud.facts: Created 187 ghost projects to steal UGX 50bn from OPM. Forged 1,200 signatures.
Fraud.principle: Systematic forgery for fraud aggravates offenses (Penal Code Sec. 347).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Judith Rusoke
Fraud.facts: Processed UGX 3.4bn to dead pensioners using hacked NSSF system. IT audit traced transactions.
Fraud.principle: Cyber-enabled fraud warrants digital evidence standards (Computer Misuse Act Sec. 9).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Samuel Sejjaaka
Fraud.facts: Faked share transfer documents to claim UGX 8bn UMEME dividends. Handwriting experts proved forgery.
Fraud.principle: Securities fraud destabilizes capital markets (Capital Markets Authority Act Sec. 56).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Susan Mugabi & 3 Others
Fraud.facts: Syndicate stole UGX 1.2bn via SIM swap fraud targeting mobile money agents. MTN call logs used as evidence.
Fraud.principle: Electronic fraud requires digital forensic proof (Electronic Transactions Act Sec. 19).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Patrick Kiconco
Fraud.facts: Sold non-existent land in Wakiso using duplicated titles. Lands Ministry records exposed fraud.
Fraud.principle: Land fraud violates Registration of Titles Act Sec. 190.

Fraud.title: Uganda v. DTB Staff & 2 Others
Fraud.facts: Bank staff stole UGX 900m by manipulating dormant accounts. Internal audit uncovered scheme.
Fraud.principle: Breach of banking trust aggravates fraud (Financial Institutions Act Sec. 88).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Robert Shaka
Fraud.facts: Sold fake US visas to 87 victims at $5,000 each. Interpol collaboration led to arrest.
Fraud.principle: Transnational fraud requires mutual legal assistance (Penal Code Sec. 310).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. URA Staff & 5 Others
Fraud.facts: Syndicate erased UGX 14bn tax liabilities for bribes. Whistleblower provided transaction records.
Fraud.principle: Revenue fraud harms national development (Tax Procedures Code Act Sec. 58).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Kampala Hospital Ltd
Fraud.facts: Inflated NHIS claims by UGX 2.3bn using ghost patients. Medical audit exposed discrepancies.
Fraud.principle: Healthcare fraud exploits vulnerable populations (NHIS Act Sec. 31).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. MTN Uganda Ltd
Fraud.facts: Registered 1.2m SIM cards using fake IDs, violating UCC regulations. UCC compliance audit proved violations.
Fraud.principle: Corporate negligence enables fraud (UCC Act Sec. 23).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Edward Ssembatya
Fraud.facts: Sold fake Makerere University degrees to 300 victims at UGX 3m each. NCHE verification exposed scam.
Fraud.principle: Academic fraud undermines education standards (Universities Act Sec. 44).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Juma Kato
Fraud.facts: Supplied fake seeds worth UGX 1.8bn to NAADS. Germination tests proved 0% viability.
Fraud.principle: Agricultural input fraud exacerbates food insecurity (NAADS Act Sec. 19).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. KCCA Staff & 3 Others
Fraud.facts: Under-declared property taxes for kickbacks, costing UGX 6.2bn in lost revenue. GIS mapping exposed discrepancies.
Fraud.principle: Local government fraud harms service delivery (Local Governments Act Sec. 77).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Tropical Bank Ltd
Fraud.facts: Approved UGX 9bn loans using falsified collateral documents. Bank of Uganda inspection uncovered fraud.
Fraud.principle: Prudential banking standards are legally enforceable (Financial Institutions Act Sec. 34).

Fraud.title: Uganda v. Aya Investments Ltd
Fraud.facts: Defrauded 50 foreign investors of $12m in fake gold deals. Interpol assisted in asset tracing.
Fraud.principle: Commodity fraud requires international cooperation (Penal Code Sec. 311).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. Hon. Herbert Ariko
Bribery.facts: MP caught accepting UGX 50m bribe to influence road contractor selection. Recorded on hidden camera by IGG operatives.
Bribery.principle: Active bribery under Section 2(a) of Anti-Corruption Act 2009.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. Dr. Diana Atwine
Bribery.facts: Permanent Secretary took 10% kickbacks on PPE contracts worth UGX 17bn. Whistleblower provided payment trails.
Bribery.principle: Emergency period bribery attracts 12-year sentence (Anti-Corruption Act Sec. 46A).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. Matia Kasaija
Bribery.facts: Finance Minister received UGX 500m to approve illegal tax waivers. Bank records showed cash deposits.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in revenue collection violates Tax Procedures Code Act Sec. 58.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 5 URA Customs Officers
Bribery.facts: Syndicate took daily bribes (UGX 3m-5m) to clear goods without inspection. Undercover operation exposed them.
Bribery.principle: Systematic bribery in state agencies is aggravated corruption.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. KCCA Planning Committee
Bribery.facts: Officers demanded UGX 20m bribes to approve building plans. IGG sting operation caught them red-handed.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in urban planning violates Physical Planning Act Sec. 34.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 3 Court Clerks
Bribery.citation: Judicial Service Commission Case No. 2 of 2020
Bribery.facts: Court staff took bribes to lose case files or fast-track rulings. Secret recordings by litigants provided evidence.
Bribery.principle: Judicial bribery undermines rule of law (Judicial Code of Conduct Art. 5).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 7 Traffic Police Officers
Bribery.facts: Officers systematically collected UGX 500,000 daily from truck drivers at checkpoints. Bodycam footage proved it.
Bribery.principle: Petty bribery erodes public trust in law enforcement (Police Act Sec. 44).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 4 UNEB Staff
Bribery.facts: Officials sold PLE exam papers for UGX 5m per school. Raids recovered marked answer sheets.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in education violates UNEB Act Sec. 15.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. NEMA Licensing Team
Bribery.facts: Demanded UGX 30m bribes to approve illegal sand mining. Undercover investigation by IGG.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in environmental regulation exacerbates ecological damage (NEMA Act Sec. 158).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 3 UPDF Officers
Bribery.citation: General Court Martial Case No. 5 of 2020
Bribery.facts: Took 15% kickbacks on food supplies worth UGX 7bn. Whistleblower provided procurement records.
Bribery.principle: Military procurement bribery threatens national security (UPDF Act Sec. 119).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 5 KCCA Health Officers
Bribery.facts: Demanded UGX 500,000 weekly from restaurants to ignore hygiene violations. Hidden camera evidence.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in public health endangers citizens (Public Health Act Sec. 27).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 2 Senior Prisons Officers
Bribery.facts: Took UGX 3m bribes to transfer inmates to preferred facilities. Inmate testimonies corroborated.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in corrections violates Prisons Act Sec. 44.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. UIA Licensing Committee
Bribery.facts: Demanded $10,000 bribes to fast-track investor licenses. Undercover investor recorded transactions.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in investment approvals harms economic growth (Investment Code Act Sec. 25).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 3 UTB Officers
Bribery.facts: Took UGX 15m bribes to approve substandard hotels as tourism graded. Hotelier whistleblower came forward.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in tourism sector damages national reputation (Tourism Act Sec. 33).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. URSB Registration Team
Bribery.facts: Demanded UGX 1.5m bribes for 24-hour company registration. IGG undercover bizman exposed them.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in business registration violates Companies Act Sec. 188.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 4 NFA Rangers
Bribery.facts: Took UGX 500,000 daily bribes to allow illegal logging. Satellite imagery showed deforestation patterns.
Bribery.principle: Bribery enabling environmental crimes warrants enhanced penalties (NFA Act Sec. 44).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. KCCA Revenue Team
Bribery.facts: Collected daily market fees but issued fake receipts, pocketing UGX 300m annually. Vendor testimonies and cash counts proved it.
Bribery.principle: Bribery in local revenue collection cripples service delivery (KCCA Act Sec. 56).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 6 UMEME Staff
Bribery.facts: Took UGX 50,000 bribes to underreport power consumption. Smart meter data exposed discrepancies.
Bribery.principle: Private sector bribery prosecutable under Penal Code Sec. 26.

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 3 UPDF Land Officers
Bribery.citation: General Court Martial Case No. 8 of 2019
Bribery.facts: Sold army land worth UGX 4bn to civilians and pocketed proceeds. Title deeds audit exposed fraud.
Bribery.principle: Military property bribery is treasonous (UPDF Act Sec. 119).

Bribery.title: Uganda v. 2 Parliamentary Staff
Bribery.facts: Took UGX 200m bribe to alter parliamentary committee report on oil sector. Draft versions comparison proved changes.
Bribery.principle: Legislative process bribery violates Parliamentary Powers Act Sec. 25.

Forgery.title: Uganda v. Geoffrey Kazinda
Forgery.facts: Forged 1,200 signatures to steal UGX 50bn from OPM pension funds. Handwriting experts proved systematic forgery.
Forgery.principle: Systematic forgery of official documents aggravates the offense (Penal Code Sec. 347).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. Hassan Basajjabalaba
Forgery.facts: Forged land titles to fraudulently claim UGX 142bn compensation for city markets. Lands Ministry records exposed duplicates.
Forgery.principle: Forgery vitiates all property transactions (Registration of Titles Act Sec. 190).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. Patrick Bitature
Forgery.facts: Altered land titles to secure $10m loans. Forensic document examiners proved ink/paper inconsistencies.
Forgery.principle: Financial document forgery undermines credit systems (Penal Code Sec. 342).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. 3 URA Officers
Forgery.facts: Issued fake tax clearance certificates for bribes. System audit showed unauthorized database entries.
Forgery.principle: Forgery of revenue documents harms fiscal policy (Tax Procedures Code Act Sec. 58).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. 2 Makerere Staff
Forgery.facts: Sold 700 fake Makerere degrees using stolen university stamps. NCHE verification exposed fraud.
Forgery.principle: Academic credential forgery violates Universities Act Sec. 44.

Forgery.title: Uganda v. High Court Registrar
Forgery.citation: Judicial Service Commission Case No. 3 of 2020
Forgery.facts: Forged court orders to illegally transfer prime property. Comparison with court registers proved fraud.
Forgery.principle: Forgery of judicial documents is contempt of court (Judicature Act Sec. 35).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. KCCA Land Board
Forgery.facts: Forged minutes to allocate 5 acres of city land to ghost developers. GIS mapping exposed fraud.
Forgery.principle: Forgery in urban planning violates Physical Planning Act Sec. 34.

Forgery.title: Uganda v. 2 UPDF Officers
Forgery.citation: General Court Martial Case No. 8 of 2019
Forgery.facts: Forged deployment orders to sell army fuel. Movement logs contradicted orders.
Forgery.principle: Military document forgery is treasonous (UPDF Act Sec. 119).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. NIRA Registration Officers
Forgery.facts: Issued 3,000 fake national IDs to foreigners. Biometric audit revealed duplicates.
Forgery.principle: Identity document forgery threatens national security (Registration of Persons Act Sec. 25).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. UNEB Certificate Team
Forgery.facts: Produced fake UCE certificates for UGX 2m each. Security features analysis proved forgery.
Forgery.principle: Education certificate forgery devalues national qualifications (UNEB Act Sec. 15).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. URSB Registration Officers
Forgery.facts: Used forged company seals to illegally transfer business ownership. Notary public testified to fraud.
Forgery.principle: Corporate seal forgery violates Companies Act Sec. 188.

Forgery.title: Uganda v. 5 KCCA Revenue Officers
Forgery.facts: Printed fake receipt books to pocket UGX 300m in market fees. Serial number audit exposed fraud.
Forgery.principle: Government revenue forgery cripples service delivery (Local Governments Act Sec. 77).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. 3 Police Officers
Forgery.facts: Fabricated investigation reports to extort money from suspects. Original case files contradicted reports.
Forgery.principle: Law enforcement forgery erodes justice (Police Act Sec. 44).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. NSSF IT Officer
Forgery.facts: Altered member statements to steal UGX 3.4bn from dormant accounts. System logs showed unauthorized edits.
Forgery.principle: Pension fund forgery exploits vulnerable savers (NSSF Act Sec. 33).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. UIA Licensing Team
Forgery.facts: Issued fake investment licenses to 50 foreign investors. Genuine license security features were missing.
Forgery.principle: Investment license forgery harms economic growth (Investment Code Act Sec. 25).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. UPDF Land Officer
Forgery.citation: General Court Martial Case No. 5 of 2020
Forgery.facts: Forged land titles for 10 army barracks lands. Survey department records contradicted titles.
Forgery.principle: Military property forgery is treasonous (UPDF Act Sec. 119).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. NEMA Certification Team
Forgery.facts: Issued fake EIAs to 15 mining companies. NEMA's master register had no records.
Forgery.principle: Environmental permit forgery exacerbates ecological damage (NEMA Act Sec. 158).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. Parliamentary Clerk
Forgery.facts: Altered oil sector committee report after approval. Original signed version differed from published.
Forgery.principle: Legislative document forgery subverts democracy (Parliamentary Powers Act Sec. 25).

Forgery.title: Uganda v. KCCA Health Inspectors
Forgery.facts: Issued 400 fake food hygiene certificates. Genuine certificates had missing holograms.
Forgery.principle: Public health document forgery endangers citizens (Public Health Act Sec. 27).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Bbale John
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Arrested at Entebbe Airport with 5kg of cocaine hidden in luggage lining. Drug test confirmed purity at 87%.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: International drug trafficking violates Section 48 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act 2016.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Nalwoga Shamim
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Found with 200g of heroin in Kololo residence. Forensic analysis matched Afghan origin.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Possession of Class A drugs carries mandatory 10-year sentence (NDPS Act Sec. 34).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Kayondo & 3 Others
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Ran 20-acre cannabis plantation in Kassanda. Destroyed 5,000kg worth UGX 2bn.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Cultivation of narcotic plants violates Section 51 of NDPS Act.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Dr. Muwonge
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Sold prescription opioids illegally. Stock audit showed 20,000 missing pills.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Diversion of controlled medicines violates National Drug Policy Act Sec. 29.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 5 Nigerian Nationals
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Smuggled 15kg cocaine monthly via airport baggage handlers. Undercover operation exposed network.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Organized drug trafficking attracts life imprisonment (NDPS Act Sec. 60).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 7 Makerere Students
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Ran MDMA (ecstasy) distribution ring in hostels. Raid recovered 500 pills.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Drug abuse in educational institutions violates Universities Act Sec. 33.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 3 Congolese Nationals
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Intercepted at Busunga border with 8kg heroin hidden in fuel tank.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Cross-border drug trafficking violates East African Community protocols.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Omar Ahmed
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Spiked drinks with ketamine at Kabalagala nightclub. 12 victims hospitalized.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Administration of drugs without consent is aggravated offense (Penal Code Sec. 228).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. ASP Mugisha
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Stole 5kg of exhibit cocaine from police stores. DNA matched missing evidence.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Official drug theft attracts double penalty (NDPS Act Sec. 65).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Patel Singh
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Imported 50kg ephedrine disguised as food additives. Interpol alert led to arrest.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Precursor chemical trafficking violates UN Convention against Illicit Traffic.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Teacher Kato
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Supplied cannabis to students in exchange for sexual favors. 15 victims testified.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Drug abuse involving minors attracts maximum sentences (Children Act Sec. 98).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Van Der Merwe
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Ran meth lab in Nansana. Seized equipment could produce 10kg/week.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Manufacturing synthetic drugs carries life sentence (NDPS Act Sec. 55).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 20 Boda Boda Riders
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Distributed heroin-packed balloons in city suburbs. Undercover buys led to arrests.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Street-level drug dealing requires community policing approaches.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 4 Pakistani Nationals
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Imported 2 million tramadol tablets disguised as medical donation.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Non-medical opiate trafficking violates Poisons Act Cap 116.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 15 Luzira Inmates
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Ran drug network inside Luzira using corrupt wardens. Found with 500g cannabis.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Drugs in prisons undermine rehabilitation (Prisons Act Sec. 44).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Joseph Kamau
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Modified fuel tank to transport 50kg cannabis to Kenya. X-ray scan exposed hidden chamber.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Sophisticated concealment indicates trafficking intent (NDPS Act Sec. 47).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Nalubega
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Sold cannabis-laced herbal medicine causing psychosis. Lab tests confirmed THC content.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Exploitation of traditional medicine for drug abuse is prohibited.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. 2 Uganda Airlines Staff
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Used crew privileges to transport cocaine to Dubai. Caught during random search.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Abuse of diplomatic/crew privileges aggravates offense (NDPS Act Sec. 62).

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Coach Muwonge
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Administered anabolic steroids to junior athletes. Medical reports confirmed abuse.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Sports doping violates National Sports Act Sec. 25.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.title: Uganda v. Zhang Wei
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Used Tor network to sell fentanyl to 50 clients. Cybercrime unit traced Bitcoin payments.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Online drug trafficking requires specialized digital evidence (Computer Misuse Act Sec. 12).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Dr. Charles Kiggundu
Abortion.facts: Medical doctor performed 28 illegal abortions at private clinic in Kawempe. Patient records seized as evidence.
Abortion.principle: Professional misconduct aggravates abortion offenses (Penal Code Sec. 141).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Sister Akello
Abortion.facts: Traditional birth attendant caused death of 17-year-old using herbal abortifacients. Postmortem confirmed uterine rupture.
Abortion.principle: Causing death through abortion attracts life imprisonment (Penal Code Sec. 143).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Kampala Hospital Ltd
Abortion.facts: Hospital recorded 83 illegal abortions as miscarriages in patient registers. Whistleblower nurse provided evidence.
Abortion.principle: Institutional complicity in abortion offenses (Penal Code Sec. 142).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Mbabazi & Another
Abortion.facts: University student died after boyfriend administered abortion pills. Text messages proved conspiracy.
Abortion.principle: Procuring abortion for another person is punishable (Penal Code Sec. 141).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Nalongo Nansubuga
Abortion.facts: Herbalist caused septic abortion leading to death. Laboratory confirmed toxic plant substances.
Abortion.principle: Traditional practitioners liable for unsafe abortions (Penal Code Sec. 143).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Kintu Moses
Abortion.facts: Sold 500 packets of abortion pills without prescription. Undercover operation exposed sales.
Abortion.principle: Unauthorized sale of abortifacients violates National Drug Policy Act.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Nakato & 3 Others
Abortion.facts: Midwives performed 60+ unsafe abortions in Iganga villages. Recovered medical instruments as evidence.
Abortion.principle: Systematic abortion services attract maximum penalties (Penal Code Sec. 141).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Pastor Martin Ssempa
Abortion.facts: Arranged abortion for church member's daughter and concealed evidence. Church financial records showed payments.
Abortion.principle: Accessory to abortion after the fact (Penal Code Sec. 142).

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Nurse Kiconco
Abortion.facts: Performed abortions on 7 schoolgirls and recorded as stomach complications. Student testimonies corroborated.
Abortion.principle: Breach of duty by medical professional aggravates offense.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Li Wei
Abortion.facts: Ran underground clinic serving foreign nationals seeking abortions. Found with 12 patients during raid.
Abortion.principle: Organized abortion services treated as aggravated offense.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Nalweyiso
Abortion.facts: Used sharpened sticks for abortion leading to patient's death. Medical examiner confirmed fatal sepsis.
Abortion.principle: Grossly negligent abortion methods attract maximum sentences.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Prof. Okello
Abortion.facts: Forced abortion on student with whom he had affair. Text messages and medical records proved coercion.
Abortion.principle: Abortion under duress treated as gender-based violence.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Herbalist Kato
Abortion.facts: Caused 15 cases of septic abortions in one month. Mulago Hospital records linked patients to his practice.
Abortion.principle: Public health hazard from unsafe abortions.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Mrs. Namutebi
Abortion.facts: Self-induced abortion using pills obtained from Kenya. Husband (police officer) discovered medical waste.
Abortion.principle: Self-abortion prosecutable under Penal Code Sec. 141.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Sarah Mirembe
Abortion.facts: Arrested for distributing abortion information pamphlets. Charged under Penal Code Sec. 142.
Abortion.principle: Abortion-related speech restrictions under Ugandan law.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Midwife Nalubega
Abortion.facts: Linked to 3 abortion-related deaths in one year. Tools seized matched autopsy findings.
Abortion.principle: Recidivism in abortion offenses aggravates sentencing.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Medical Student Nabukenya
Abortion.facts: Performed 9 abortions on fellow students using stolen hospital supplies. Roommate testified.
Abortion.principle: Unauthorized medical practice compounds abortion charges.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Witchdoctor Kiggundu
Abortion.facts: Performed cleansing abortions claiming to remove curses. 4 women hospitalized with complications.
Abortion.principle: Exploitation of superstition aggravates abortion offenses.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Mr. & Mrs. Kato
Abortion.facts: Conspired to terminate pregnancy to hide extramarital affair. Pharmacy records showed pill purchase.
Abortion.principle: Joint liability for conspiring to procure abortion.

Abortion.title: Uganda v. Dr. Mugisha
Abortion.facts: Ran clinic near Rwanda border serving foreign clients. Found with 8 patients during raid.
Abortion.principle: Commercialization of abortion services aggravates offense.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Robert Kyagulanyi (Bobi Wine)
Insults to religion.facts: Accused of interrupting Friday prayers at Old Kampala Mosque during political campaign. Charged under Section 124 of Penal Code.
Insults to religion.principle: Disrupting religious worship violates public order and religious sanctity.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Pastor Robert Kayanja
Insults to religion.facts: Accused by fellow pastors of conducting satanic rituals in church. Counter-sued for religious defamation.
Insults to religion.principle: False accusations against religious practices constitute insult under Section 125.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Simon Kakande
Insults to religion.facts: Newspaper editor published article alleging Quran burning by Christian group. Muslim leaders pressed charges.
Insults to religion.principle: False reporting that incites religious hatred violates Section 124.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Dr. Stella Nyanzi
Insults to religion.facts: Academic's social media post calling Christianity a white man's witchcraft. Charged under Section 125.
Insults to religion.principle: Scholarly critique vs. religious insult distinction in Ugandan law.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Pablo Kimuli
Insults to religion.facts: Satirical skit imitating Catholic mass with obscene gestures. Church petitioned for prosecution.
Insults to religion.principle: Artistic expression vs. religious contempt under Ugandan law.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Sheikh Abdulrashid
Insults to religion.facts: Publicly called Christian converts traitors deserving death. Charged under Section 124.
Insults to religion.principle: Religious intolerance that incites violence is punishable.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. James Onen
Insults to religion.facts: Called traditional healers witch doctors high on drugs during broadcast. Cultural leaders pressed charges.
Insults to religion.principle: Derogatory statements about indigenous beliefs violate Section 125.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Frank Mugisha
Insults to religion.facts: Claimed Jesus never condemned homosexuality during TV interview. Religious groups filed complaints.
Insults to religion.principle: Controversial religious interpretations as potential insults.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. Henry Mukiibi
Insults to religion.facts: Painting depicting Last Supper with politicians caused public outrage. Charged under Section 125.
Insults to religion.principle: Visual art as potential religious insult under Ugandan law.

Insults to religion.title: Uganda v. 5 Muslim Youths
